One million five hundred thousand dollars "to so reorganize the
Medical School as to pay out of
the income of the gift such salaries
to the men who occupy the chairs
of medicine, surgery and pediatrics
(children's diseases) and to their
assistants as will enable them to
wholly drop their private practice
and devote their entire time, ability
and lives to the advancement of
their particular branches," was the
princely contribution to the Johns
Hopkins University given by the
General Education Board last Friday night.
The gift and the carrying out of
the sole stipulation as briefly stated
above will mark a new era in medical science. It will place the men
affected on the plane of arts and
science professors who devote their
entire time to their studies. Heretofore, professors occupying chairs
in medical schools have devoted
only certain hours to teaching, while
the remainder,of their time has been
given to consultation and private
practice.
Now the Hopkins professors of
medicine, surgery and pediatrics
will devote their entire time to the
duties of their departments, and
such time as will not be used ih
actual teaching will be spent in investigation and research. Private
practice will be given up partly,
but the professors will not accept
any fees from patients. The income of the gift will be used to
equip new laboratories and pay salaries.
The idea originated in England,
and received its first serious attention in America when it was discussed by Dr. Lewellys F. Barker,
of Hopkins, eleven years ago in a
speech at Chicago. It has been a
"hobby" with Dr. Barker, and, peculiarily enough, he will be one of
the men affected by the gift. He
is professor of medicine.
The other men besides Dr.
Barker who, with their assistants,
will carry out the plan are: Dr.
W. S. Halsted, professor of surgery; Dr. John Howland, professor of pediatrics.
That such a reorganization of
these branches of medicine has long
been contemplated by the medical
staff is well known to Hopkins men.
Di. William H. Welch, head of
the University, since the resignation of Dr. Remsen, went to New

In spite of a heavy downpour of
rain which lasted throughout the
game, and the field covered with
water and mud, the football team
played and won its game against
Stevens Institute at Hoboken last
Saturday. Although neither team
was able to score during the first
two quarters, Hopkins came back
strong in the last part of the game
and played the Hoboken team off
its feet. The final score was: Hopkins, 12; Stevens, o.
The two elevens were about equal
in weight, with a slight advantage
in favor of Stevens. Due to the
slippery condition of the ball,
fumbles were numerous on both
sides. The earlier part of the game
was entirely straight football, both
elevens repeatedly plugging their
opponent's line. Towards the end,
however, Hopkins opened up and
played a passing game, which
proved successful against the Red
and White.
At 2.45 Stevens kicked off to
Bowers, who returned the ball to
mid-field before he was downed.
Hopkins then rushed the ball to
Stevens' 20-yard line, only to lose
it on a fumble. By a series of end
runs and line plunges, Stevens
worked the ball to Hopkins' 30-yard
line, when the whistle blew. Honors were about even in this period.
The Black and Blue team started
the second quarter by recovering a
fumble, thereby depriving the Hoboken eleven of an excellent opportunity to score. Hopkins was
unable to make any impression on
the opponent's line, and was forced
to kick. The heavy ends, called
into the backfield, were unable to
get started when they hit the
Stevens line. Stevens attempted a
forward pass, but was unsuccessful.
Near the end of the second quarter,
Tippett tried a drop-kick, but the
soggy ground and wet ball allowed
of no success. Score: Hopkins, o;
Stevens, o.
At the opening of the third period, Hopkins made her first touchdown, when Tippett caught a punt
and circled Stevens' end for a
touchdown. The try for goal was
missed. The period ended with
Hopkins ahead. Score: Hdpkins,
6; Stevens, o.
The Red and White could gain
no ground against the Hopkins
line in the last quarter, and was

Pictorial story of progress on Gilman Hall, the central building of
the new Johns Hopkins University on the Homewood estate. Masonry

and steel construction are rapidly giving physical form to the colonial
structure that was for a long time the dream of Hopkins trustees, faculty
and students.

Gilman Hall is the main figure of the arts and science "quad." To
the south the buildings of the "tech quad" are beginning to rise from
their concrete foundations. The story of their progress will be pictured
in a later issue.

The organization meeting of the
Grotius Society will be held next
Tuesday, October 28th, at one
o'clock, in the Donovan Room. All
students of the University are invited to attend. For the benefit of
the new men in the University, we
may briefly state that the Grotius
Society (pronounced grow-shous)
fills the place of the customary
"literary" society. Its meetings are
held in order to discuss any matter
whatsoever within the realms of the
arts and the sciences that may be of
interest to its members. Any one
may become a rpember ; merely attend the meetings. The first meeting—Tuesday, at one o'clock, Donovan Room.

Who's to Foot the Bill?

With the facilities the Johns
Hopkins Hospital offers us, it is a
rather careless policy to have a
very ill-defined notion about_ who is
to "foot the bill" for "professional
services" when a football player is
injured at Homewood.
While for all minor injuries we
have the ever-faithful "Abber,"
yet for serious ones additional
medical service is often required,
and the. injured player frequently
has to pay his own bill.
Fortunately, however, these serious injuries are very rare; but when
they do occur the family of the injured player is in doubt' as to how
far its responsibility goes. It is
in the uncomfortable position of a
possible recipient of charity. .
There does not seem to be a
clearly-defined law in the Athletic
Association's constitution covering
cases of this kind. The matter

Beware, 1916!

THE NEWS-LETTER published an
interesting letter from "Freshman"
last week, in which the correspondent tells of the "September Morn"
stunt which the sophomores have
been playing recently on the freshmen, to wit: dipping them in the
"flowing estuary" in Mount Vernon Place.
It appears that several such imitations of the picture that made
Chicago famous have been posed
by freshmen. All of them, however, have been done so quietly, so
subtly, that there have been no
Frank Brown, Jr., consequences.
But—
THE NEWS-LETTER was told confidentially by a freshman of the deliberations of a recent meeting.
Beware, 1916!
Keep Them Up.

Regular cheering practice and
sending off the team with yells, begun last week, are innovations
which should rapidly become "customs."
Although most of the songs and
yells are easy to memorize, the
"Hullabaloo" yell and several others
require considerable practice.
Fifteen minutes' "rehearsing"
every Wednesday should work
wonders in the volume and correctness of the cheering. We congratulate the "Boosters' Club" for
getting the yell practices going.
But, particularly, should the custom of cheering off a departing
team become established.
If it knows that the student body
really cares whether it comes back
conqueror or conquered, a team
will fight ten times harder. In a
small town, going to the station to
give the team a "send-off" is an
easy matter, and the railroad depot
is usually the only place of interest.
Here, where the fellows must cut
lab, or the theatre to go to Union
Station, some self-denial is called
forth.
But it's the old story of what
you give to Alma Mater, she will
give to you. Think how dull your
memories of Hopkins would be, did
they merely concern "points movabout a circle with a constant acceleration," or some equally nonsensical proposition!

THE CO-OPERATIVE SYSTEM
Patronize the Advertisers and Get Paid
for Doing It—Read the
List Below.

In the first two issues of THE
NEWS-LETTER there appeared articles to the effect that we would
be glad to pay Hopkins students
to patronize our advertisers. We
repeat the statement and, in order
to facilitate co-operation, we are
printing in this issue an alphabetical list of advertisers, which will
be reprinted on a card and given
to all those who have postoffice
boxes at the University. The list
includes two or three of the best
representatives of Baltimore's leading stores.
All that you have to do is to
keep the card in your pocket and
when you find that you need a
couple of shirts, or an overcoat, or
a suit of clothes, or a pair of shoes,
or anything that can be bought
from an advertiser, simply consult
the card, make the purchase at one
of the advertisers, and get him to
give you a bill or anything that will
show the amount of the purchase.
Return this bill or receipt to THE
NEWS-LETTER and get paid for
it in the form of money, if the,
purchase is large, or in sodas, sundaes, candy, cigarettes, etc., if the
purchase is small.
We naturally give more for receipts from some advertisers than
for others, depending on the size of
their advertisement and the ease
with which we can supply them
with trade. Therefore, to make the
system more exact, we shall post on
THE NEWS-LETTER bulletin board
in the elevator the exact percentage
given on a purchase from each advertiser.

J. H. U. MUSICIANS GET BUSY

ST. TIMOTHY'S WANTS MAN

Glee Club Has Rousing Good Opening
Rehearsal - Instrumentalists
Prepare for Season.

Go Early and Avoid Rush—Must Take
Girls on Walks Y. M. C. A.
Man Preferred.

The Glee Club began active work
last Wednesday afternoon in McCoy Hall at 1.15 o'clock. Leader
Lloyd was well pleased with the attendance of between thirty-five and
forty men. He gave them a short
talk, outlined the work to be done,
the plan to be followed, and the responsibility and duties of Glee Club
members. With so much competition it will become a more difficult
job to secure a place on the club,
and a number of qualifications will
be demanded of all successful candidates—regular attendance, promptness, attention and behavior, together with ability to carry the tune
and learn the "part," will all be
taken. into consideration in the selection of the men who go on the club
trips.
Regular practices will begin this
week. The first and second tenors
will rehearse on Mondays; the
bassos on Wednesdays ; and the entire club will meet for joint rehearsals on Fridays. At first the
regular Hopkins songs will be
learned. An excellent beginning
was made at this last Wednesday.
The new men were by no means
slow in "catching on" to the swing
of "Stonie's" song, and in the
course of a few days they are expected to know the full list. By
this time the new music will have
arrived and hard work will begin.
Leader Geissel of the Instrumental Club requests all who can
play mandolin, piano, violin, guitar
or 'cello to watch the bulletin board
for announcements. Announcement
will be made of the first rehearsal
as soon as the new music arrives.
Don't miss the first practices, and
thus be handicapped at the start.

Both Neglected.

There is a saying that a man who
squeezes a dollar never squeezes his
wife. After glancing over his subscription book, a country editor is
led to remark that there are a number of good married women in his
county who arc not getting the attention they deserve.—E.r.

CATONSVILLE,

October 26, 1913.
The Chairman, Bureau of Appointments, Johns Hopkins University.
DEAR SIR—We have long desired the services of a Johns Hopkins student to take our girls out
walking. Our plan of having lady
teachers has not proved satisfactory—they cannot stir up the same
enthusiasm that a young man can.
If possible let us have a man who
has a good field knowledge of botany and natural history. I suppose
it is unnecessary to add that the
man you recommend be of high
moral character, and preferably a
leader in the Y. M. C. A.
Yours truly,
Miss PROWLER, Principal.
P. S.—The man must have passed
his first year in college.
The above has been received by
the Bureau of Appointments. Owing to the large number of applicants, the man will be selected by
lot; the drawing to be held in
Levering Hall on Wednesday afternoon at one o'clock.
The following men have applied:
Lawrence Getz, Del Valle, Schloss,
Vickers, Niles, Hahn, Lynch, Leland, Knipp, Nelson, Lauchheimer,
Hammond, Huck, Corner, Biser,
Richardson, Supplee, Tinges, "Sookey" Ford, Gus Sattler, '13.
Any one who wishes to enter,
should send his name immediately
to H. M. Wagner, Secretary of Y.
M. C. A., Levering Hall.

the husband returning from business, was grieved to find his little
wife crying bitterly.
"Oh, George," she sobbed, "such
a dreadful thing has happened. I
had made you a beautiful pie all
myself, and Fido went and ate it."
"Well, never mind, my dear," he
said cheerfully, "we can easily buy
another dog."

One million five hundred thousand dollars "to so reorganize the
Medical School as to pay out of
the income of the gift such salaries
to the men who occupy the chairs
of medicine, surgery and pediatrics
(children's diseases) and to their
assistants as will enable them to
wholly drop their private practice
and devote their entire time, ability
and lives to the advancement of
their particular branches," was the
princely contribution to the Johns
Hopkins University given by the
General Education Board last Friday night.
The gift and the carrying out of
the sole stipulation as briefly stated
above will mark a new era in medical science. It will place the men
affected on the plane of arts and
science professors who devote their
entire time to their studies. Heretofore, professors occupying chairs
in medical schools have devoted
only certain hours to teaching, while
the remainder,of their time has been
given to consultation and private
practice.
Now the Hopkins professors of
medicine, surgery and pediatrics
will devote their entire time to the
duties of their departments, and
such time as will not be used ih
actual teaching will be spent in investigation and research. Private
practice will be given up partly,
but the professors will not accept
any fees from patients. The income of the gift will be used to
equip new laboratories and pay salaries.
The idea originated in England,
and received its first serious attention in America when it was discussed by Dr. Lewellys F. Barker,
of Hopkins, eleven years ago in a
speech at Chicago. It has been a
"hobby" with Dr. Barker, and, peculiarily enough, he will be one of
the men affected by the gift. He
is professor of medicine.
The other men besides Dr.
Barker who, with their assistants,
will carry out the plan are: Dr.
W. S. Halsted, professor of surgery; Dr. John Howland, professor of pediatrics.
That such a reorganization of
these branches of medicine has long
been contemplated by the medical
staff is well known to Hopkins men.
Di. William H. Welch, head of
the University, since the resignation of Dr. Remsen, went to New

In spite of a heavy downpour of
rain which lasted throughout the
game, and the field covered with
water and mud, the football team
played and won its game against
Stevens Institute at Hoboken last
Saturday. Although neither team
was able to score during the first
two quarters, Hopkins came back
strong in the last part of the game
and played the Hoboken team off
its feet. The final score was: Hopkins, 12; Stevens, o.
The two elevens were about equal
in weight, with a slight advantage
in favor of Stevens. Due to the
slippery condition of the ball,
fumbles were numerous on both
sides. The earlier part of the game
was entirely straight football, both
elevens repeatedly plugging their
opponent's line. Towards the end,
however, Hopkins opened up and
played a passing game, which
proved successful against the Red
and White.
At 2.45 Stevens kicked off to
Bowers, who returned the ball to
mid-field before he was downed.
Hopkins then rushed the ball to
Stevens' 20-yard line, only to lose
it on a fumble. By a series of end
runs and line plunges, Stevens
worked the ball to Hopkins' 30-yard
line, when the whistle blew. Honors were about even in this period.
The Black and Blue team started
the second quarter by recovering a
fumble, thereby depriving the Hoboken eleven of an excellent opportunity to score. Hopkins was
unable to make any impression on
the opponent's line, and was forced
to kick. The heavy ends, called
into the backfield, were unable to
get started when they hit the
Stevens line. Stevens attempted a
forward pass, but was unsuccessful.
Near the end of the second quarter,
Tippett tried a drop-kick, but the
soggy ground and wet ball allowed
of no success. Score: Hopkins, o;
Stevens, o.
At the opening of the third period, Hopkins made her first touchdown, when Tippett caught a punt
and circled Stevens' end for a
touchdown. The try for goal was
missed. The period ended with
Hopkins ahead. Score: Hdpkins,
6; Stevens, o.

no ground against the Hopkins
line in the last quarter, and was

Who's to Foot the Bill?

With the facilities the Johns
Hopkins Hospital offers us, it is a
rather careless policy to have a
very ill-defined notion about_ who is
to "foot the bill" for "professional
services" when a football player is
injured at Homewood.
While for all minor injuries we
have the ever-faithful "Abber,"
yet for serious ones additional
medical service is often required,
and the. injured player frequently
has to pay his own bill.
Fortunately, however, these serious injuries are very rare; but when
they do occur the family of the injured player is in doubt' as to how

in the uncomfortable position of a
possible recipient of charity. .
There does not seem to be a
clearly-defined law in the Athletic

THE NEWS-LETTER published an
interesting letter from "Freshman"
last week, in which the correspondent tells of the "September Morn"
stunt which the sophomores have
been playing recently on the freshmen, to wit: dipping them in the
"flowing estuary" in Mount Vernon Place.
It appears that several such imitations of the picture that made
Chicago famous have been posed
by freshmen. All of them, however, have been done so quietly, so
subtly, that there have been no
Frank Brown, Jr., consequences.
But—
THE NEWS-LETTER was told confidentially by a freshman of the deliberations of a recent meeting.
Beware, 1916!
Keep Them Up.

Regular cheering practice and
sending off the team with yells, begun last week, are innovations
which should rapidly become "customs."
Although most of the songs and
yells are easy to memorize, the
"Hullabaloo" yell and several others
require considerable practice.
Fifteen minutes' "rehearsing"
every Wednesday should work
wonders in the volume and correctness of the cheering. We congratulate the "Boosters' Club" for
getting the yell practices going.
But, particularly, should the custom of cheering off a departing
team become established.
If it knows that the student body
really cares whether it comes back
conqueror or conquered, a team
will fight ten times harder. In a
small town, going to the station to
give the team a "send-off" is an
easy matter, and the railroad depot
is usually the only place of interest.
Here, where the fellows must cut
lab, or the theatre to go to Union
Station, some self-denial is called
forth.
But it's the old story of what
you give to Alma Mater, she will
give to you. Think how dull your
memories of Hopkins would be, did
they merely concern "points movabout a circle with a constant acceleration," or some equally nonsensical proposition!

THE CO-OPERATIVE SYSTEM
Patronize the Advertisers and Get Paid
for Doing It—Read the

In the first two issues of THE
NEWS-LETTER there appeared articles to the effect that we would
be glad to pay Hopkins students
to patronize our advertisers. We
repeat the statement and, in order
to facilitate co-operation, we are
printing in this issue an alphabetical list of advertisers, which will
be reprinted on a card and given
to all those who have postoffice
boxes at the University. The list
includes two or three of the best
representatives of Baltimore's leading stores.
All that you have to do is to
keep the card in your pocket and
when you find that you need a
couple of shirts, or an overcoat, or
a suit of clothes, or a pair of shoes,
or anything that can be bought
from an advertiser, simply consult
the card, make the purchase at one
of the advertisers, and get him to
give you a bill or anything that will
show the amount of the purchase.
Return this bill or receipt to THE
NEWS-LETTER and get paid for
it in the form of money, if the,
purchase is large, or in sodas, sundaes, candy, cigarettes, etc., if the
purchase is small.
We naturally give more for receipts from some advertisers than
for others, depending on the size of
their advertisement and the ease
with which we can supply them
with trade. Therefore, to make the
system more exact, we shall post on
THE NEWS-LETTER bulletin board
in the elevator the exact percentage
given on a purchase from each advertiser.

J. H. U. MUSICIANS GET BUSY

ST. TIMOTHY'S WANTS MAN

Glee Club Has Rousing Good Opening
Rehearsal - Instrumentalists
Prepare for Season.

Go Early and Avoid Rush—Must Take
Girls on Walks Y. M. C. A.
Man Preferred.

The Glee Club began active work
last Wednesday afternoon in McCoy Hall at 1.15 o'clock. Leader
Lloyd was well pleased with the attendance of between thirty-five and
forty men. He gave them a short
talk, outlined the work to be done,
the plan to be followed, and the responsibility and duties of Glee Club
members. With so much competition it will become a more difficult
job to secure a place on the club,
and a number of qualifications will
be demanded of all successful candidates—regular attendance, promptness, attention and behavior, together with ability to carry the tune
and learn the "part," will all be
taken. into consideration in the selection of the men who go on the club
trips.
Regular practices will begin this
week. The first and second tenors
will rehearse on Mondays; the
bassos on Wednesdays ; and the entire club will meet for joint rehearsals on Fridays. At first the
regular Hopkins songs will be
learned. An excellent beginning
was made at this last Wednesday.
The new men were by no means
slow in "catching on" to the swing
of "Stonie's" song, and in the
course of a few days they are expected to know the full list. By
this time the new music will have
arrived and hard work will begin.
Leader Geissel of the Instrumental Club requests all who can
play mandolin, piano, violin, guitar
or 'cello to watch the bulletin board
for announcements. Announcement
will be made of the first rehearsal
as soon as the new music arrives.
Don't miss the first practices, and
thus be handicapped at the start.

Both Neglected.

There is a saying that a man who
squeezes a dollar never squeezes his
wife. After glancing over his subscription book, a country editor is
led to remark that there are a number of good married women in his
county who arc not getting the attention they deserve.—E.r.

CATONSVILLE,

October 26, 1913.
The Chairman, Bureau of Appointments, Johns Hopkins University.
DEAR SIR—We have long desired the services of a Johns Hopkins student to take our girls out
walking. Our plan of having lady
teachers has not proved satisfactory—they cannot stir up the same
enthusiasm that a young man can.
If possible let us have a man who
has a good field knowledge of botany and natural history. I suppose
it is unnecessary to add that the
man you recommend be of high
moral character, and preferably a
leader in the Y. M. C. A.
Yours truly,
Miss PROWLER, Principal.
P. S.—The man must have passed
his first year in college.
The above has been received by
the Bureau of Appointments. Owing to the large number of applicants, the man will be selected by
lot; the drawing to be held in
Levering Hall on Wednesday afternoon at one o'clock.
The following men have applied:
Lawrence Getz, Del Valle, Schloss,
Vickers, Niles, Hahn, Lynch, Leland, Knipp, Nelson, Lauchheimer,
Hammond, Huck, Corner, Biser,
Richardson, Supplee, Tinges, "Sookey" Ford, Gus Sattler, '13.
Any one who wishes to enter,
should send his name immediately
to H. M. Wagner, Secretary of Y.
M. C. A., Levering Hall.
